title: CVE-2023-27533: Telnet option IAC injection

profile.name: curl
profile.about: cURL is an Open Source project providing a library and command-line tool for doing internet transfers

vulnerability_information:
## Summary:
`CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` allows setting various telnet options for telnet protocol. Due to missing encoding of "Interpret as Command" `IAC` (0xff) character, the attacker who can control these option values can escape out of the telnet subnegotiation and enter arbitrary TELNET commands (*) via the `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS`  options. `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` and `NEW_ENV` options are affected.

*) TELNET command refers to "TELNET COMMAND STRUCTURE" in RFC 854

## Steps To Reproduce:

  1. `curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0INJECTED") telnet://server`

When inspected with tcpdump:
```
20:57:34.454720 IP x.x.x.x.53864 > y.y.y.y.telnet: Flags [P.], seq 17:37, ack 22, win 2058, options [nop,nop,TS val 1459077881 ecr 3403052525], length 20 [telnet SB NEW-ENVIRON IS 0 0x61 0x1 0x62 SE]
        0x0000:  4502 0048 0000 4000 4006 265a XXXX XXXX   E..H..@.@.&ZXXXX
        0x0010:  YYYY YYYY d268 0017 12a4 daa2 6603 9cb6  YYYY.h......f...
        0x0020:  8018 080a f840 0000 0101 080a 56f7 c2f9  .....@......V...
        0x0030:  cad6 75ed fffa 2700 0061 0162 fff0 494e  ..u...'..a.b..IN
        0x0040:  4a45 4354 4544 fff0                      JECTED..

```

## Remediation
  - Double encode "Interpret as Command" (`IAC`) (0xff) if it is encountered when constructing the suboption data to be sent.

## Supporting Material/References:
 *  RFC 854 - https://www.rfc-editor.org/rfc/rfc854

## Impact

Attacker being able to specify `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` or `NEW_ENV` values is able to inject unintended TELNET commands to the telnet connection. Depending on the use case of the telnet protocol, this may allow the attacker to inject commands or other controlling operations. The practical impact is context specific, but in worst case this could for example allow executing arbitrary OS commands on target system.

weakness.name: Failure to Sanitize Special Elements into a Different Plane (Special Element Injection)

activities.message: I'm not sure that double encoding is actually correct in this context (It is mentioned in the RFC that it's needed for the data itself, at least). It might be safer to filter out the `0xff` bytes out from the telnet option values instead.

Thank you for your report!

We will take some time and investigate your reports and get back to you with details and possible follow-up questions as soon as we can!
Another vector is via username, as it will be formatted to `"USER,%s"` and then appended to the environment list.

The situation where this would be exploitable involves scenarios where libcurl or curl is used to access service via telnet. In these scenarios the attacker would not have direct access to the target telnet port, but could define either username, `TTYPE`, `XDISPLOC` or parts of `NEW_ENV` used.

TELNET is an inherently insecure protocol and sending an extra IAC to a server can still only execute a command that the user is allowed to perform. It does not circumvent any auth.

TELNET servers are also virtually extinct and I have yet to see an actual libcurl application using `CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS`. While this is a real bug with a potential security impact, I cannot see how we can set anything higher than severity **low** for it.

`CURLOPT_TELNETOPTIONS` isn't the only vector however, the injection could sneak in via username as well. Either way, I can't really argue the severity assessment. Telnet is all but dead. I guess it might show up in some really really low end IoT still, but even those are typically capable of SSH these days.

> but in worst case this could for example allow executing arbitrary OS commands on target system.

How would that worst case work?

It is possible to inject content that is interpreted as input as if entered in the data stream. This PoC injects `root` to as login name when using Debian/GNU Linux unstable `telnetd-ssl` package:
```
$ curl --telnet-option NEW_ENV=a,b$(echo -ne "\xff\xf0\xff\xf5root") telnet://hostname
��Debian GNU/Linux 12

hostname login: root
```
NOTE: In this example user interaction is required in form of hitting 'return' 5 times.

In auth.log:
`2023-03-06T16:36:50.451367+00:00 hostname login[301254]: pam_unix(login:auth): authentication failure; logname= uid=0 euid=0 tty=/dev/pts/17 ruser= rhost=x.x.x.x  user=root`

This is of course only a partial example and not direct proof of command injection. It does prove that injecting to the data stream is possible, however. This is why I believe command injection is also possible, even though I don't currently have actual example of it.

> It is possible to inject content that is interpreted as input as if entered in the data stream

Ok, yes, I don't think that's exactly "executing arbitrary OS commands" even if it could end up being that. I would call it "passing arbitrary content to the server".

In most cases, you are communicating with a TELNET server and the client sends data to the server anyway so injecting it via the libcurl options is pointless since curl will read from stdin and send that to the server, so you can just insert whatever you want in that stream.

The only security problem this opens up is when someone can only affect the contents for one or both of these options but not control what's sent as data to the server. A rather narrow niche of use cases.

Right, and that's why used "in worst case". That scenario indeed involves a situation where the attacker would not be able to send commands direct, but could affect values for these options somehow. This is a rare situation for sure.

The injected data is also sent before even a password prompt has had the chance to appear (since passwords are weirdly not handled by TELNET itself) so the amount of mischief you can do with this is certainly limited.

Can this be any more than severity **Low**?
Considering the factors (rarely used functionality, injection being pre-auth), Low seems most appropriate, indeed.
This will fix it for sure. Technically speaking checking for >= CURL_SE would be more accurate, but would require some casting I guess (as char might be signed).

I should probably make the argument an unsigned anyway I think to make things clearer. I went with a basic ascii test  as it seemed the safest route and this can't possibly work with any unicode encodings anyway.

Yeah, it's fine. It could break some things that try to be clever and support latin1 or something like that, but I seriously doubt there is much code around that would attempt that. And even if there was, I would argue that using non-ASCII (7-bit) chars for these options is generally not correct.
https://github.com/curl/curl/pull/10728
This problem has existed since at least [a1d6ad2610](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/a1d6ad26100bc493c7b0) - Feb 20 2001

First take on advisory:

---

CVE-2023-27533: TELNET option IAC injection
============================================

Project curl Security Advisory, March 20th 2023 -
[Permalink](https://curl.se/docs/CVE-2023-27533.html)

VULNERABILITY
-------------

curl supports communicating using the TELNET protocol and as a part of this it
offers users to pass on user name and "telnet options" for the server
negotiation.

Due to lack of proper input scrubbing and without it being the documented
functionality, curl would pass on user name and telnet options to the server
as provided. This could allow users to pass in carefully crafted content that
pass on content or do option negotiation without the application intending to
do so. In particular if an application for example allows users to provide the
data or parts of the data.

We are not aware of any exploit of this flaw.

INFO
----

CVE-2023-27533 was introduced in [commit
a1d6ad26100bc493c7](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/a1d6ad26100bc493c7),
shipped in curl 7.7.

CWE-75: Failure to Sanitize Special Elements into a Different Plane

Severity: Low

AFFECTED VERSIONS
-----------------

- Affected versions: curl 7.7 to and including 7.88.1
- Not affected versions: curl < 7.7 and curl >= 8.0.0

libcurl is used by many applications, but not always advertised as such!

THE SOLUTION
------------

Only accept ASCII user name and telnet options.

A [fix for CVE-2023-27533](https://github.com/curl/curl/commit/not-yet)

RECOMMENDATIONS
--------------

 A - Upgrade curl to version 8.0.0

 B - Apply the patch to your local version

 C - Do your own TELNET user name or option input filtering

TIMELINE
--------

This issue was reported to the curl project on March 3, 2023. We contacted
distros@openwall on March 13, 2023.

libcurl 8.0.0 was released on March 20 2023, coordinated with the publication
of this advisory.

CREDITS
-------

- Reported-by: Harry Sintonen
- Patched-by: Daniel Stenberg

Thanks a lot!
Looks good to me.
Published. This issue is now eligible for a bounty claim from [IBB](https://hackerone.com/ibb).

Thanks for your work. The actual monetary reward part for this issue is managed by the [Internet Bug Bounty](https://hackerone.com/ibb) so the curl project itself therefor sets the reward amount to **zero USD**. If you haven't already, please submit your reward request to them and refer back to this issue.
